title: Thursday, 7th June, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:11 am
BE11:11am

We're only starting ten minutes late. Take that, LSE!

Blank canvas hellooooo
wayneJ Hello
BE11:11am

We've beaten you by 50 minutes.

Alexey Hello from LSE :)
VV75 morning
Soundbuy Morning all........
Grouchmonkey Bore Da. @BE Feel free to comment on how pathetic the LSE's pricing data technology is. You know you want to.
Manxish Morning each
London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE:LSE): Last: 4,528, down 26 (-0.57%), High: 4,620, Low: 4,516, Volume: 76.26k
11:12 am
PM11:12am

Yeah, since everyone else having a tech meltdown it would have been rude not to join in

wayneJ Nobody mention five 9s reliability
nichoman Maybe the guy whose job it is to turn the LSE's big computer on overslept ?
Grouchmonkey When that's done, any comment on Kier JV please?
Pharma @BE You were less late than that price is delayed.
VV75 I heard this was a test, because after Brexit it will always be 9am opening.
BornCynic Morning
Soundbuy We get an hour extra I believe..............
Soundbuy The LSE, not here obviously.........
PM11:13am

You know the SEC also had an overnight screw up?

BE11:14am

Oh? Go on.

11:13 am
PM11:14am

Here's part of my inbox from last night

PM11:14am

Electric Dragon LSE were feeling left out after TSB and Visa screw-ups
Alexey come on guys, even the traders need a lie-in some days
PM11:14am

I thought they'd gone on a regulatory rampage

Pharma @Soundbuy, bet that has cheered everyone up. Spend an hour staring at a blank screen in the morning, and as a bonus you get to work an extra hour.
11:14 am
PM11:15am

But then....

PM11:15am

A technical issue that arose during routine maintenance caused a cache of previously issues materials to be be resent. The issue has been resolved but you may receive a limited number of additional outdated emails. We regret any inconvenience to you.

PM11:15am

A limited number?

Soundbuy Couldn't we just condense this buying/selling malarkey in to a couple of hrs anyway.......
11:15 am
PM11:15am

Well...

BornCynic Had a good one yesterday. Needed a replacement Sky dish and took the old one to the tip. Told the bloke at the tip "it still works if you want it". His reply - "nah - nobody uses that stuff anymore, they're all on kodi".You can see why Sky is up for sale................
PM11:16am

Do we know what happened in London?

PM11:16am

With the LSE?

RA hey
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Nope.

PM11:16am

Great.

BE11:16am

I'm never sure whether or not to get excited about exchange failures. They're fairly regular and for dull reasons.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

You get a bunch of people saying "HAKKORZ" and stuff.

BE11:17am

But it's nearly always benign. A patch to a server that didn't take or whatever.

littleclenches Amazon wading into the UK premier league rights game..
Soundbuy @Pharma - they'll just head to the nearest boozer with their phones for the last hr.......
Pseudonym There seems to be a spate of mysterious system outages recently..
BE11:17am

And the impact of opening at 9am rather than 8am seems to have been nil.

Shinshin 100% of exchange outages are really really prosaic.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Suggesting we could do it every day, which'd be useful.

PM11:18am

hehe, fair enough

Pseudonym TSB, Visa, LSE...
Londonbus Doesnt most trade happen in first and last hour of sessions?
Shinshin And all markets should follow the very civilised Asian example of having a formal lunch break.
BE11:18am

We had big glitches on the LSE in 2008 and 2011.

Alexey It does.
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Plus an RNS failure in 2013.

DRichi FTSE is down today now at 7704. So maybe cutting off an hour of trading has saved the UK plc some money by reducing losses.
BornCynic Poundworld? If the pound shops cannot make a living who wants to own retail shares?
BE11:19am

Robin did a handy timeline last year, for reporters wanting to fill out the bottom half of their stories with background: https://www.ft.com...-bd83-71cb60e8f08c

Pharma @Soundbuy, then why wouldn't they do that every day (and then, why stop at the last hour, if your phone's enough)
Alexey Closing auction accounts for c. 30% of total day volume and only lasts for c. 5 mins
Pseudonym Of course if these were the result of attacks, then it would be wise to keep it quiet if perhaps unethical to keep it from investors.
PM11:19am

Perfect

Tundra4 @Londonbus yeah recent trends are for more volume in soemthing like first 30 and last 30 mins of the day. all driven by AI portfolio rebalancing
11:20 am
undefined
Soundbuy Market should close for 'elevenses'
rw42 @Lonodnbus/Tundra - first 30 mins probably, reckon it makes very little difference if the first 30 mins starts at 08:00, 09:00 or any random other time!
BE11:20am

Okay, so where to begin now that we have stuff actually trading?

Pharma If you hack a company and leave a file on their system, can you now force disclosure under GDPR?
Londonbus @Tundra4 - Had lunch with an old school friend last week who's a trader. He's glum - can see AI taking his job away...
BE11:21am

Kier mentioned on the right .....

11:21 am
Kier Group PLC (KIE:LSE): Last: 990.97, down 90.03 (-8.33%), High: 1,059, Low: 986.00, Volume: 461.05k
BE11:22am

Which if you just read the tape is on a housing JV.

urgeview Glum ? if he's any good he can trade for himself
BE11:22am

The much better reason, however, is from Barclays.

Shinshin @pharma most useful market structure for natural volume (vs HFT) would be four auction pools a day. So much wasted intellect and cash goes in to the meaningless noise that is continuous trading.
Londonbus @urgeview - He went into the City as he hoped to retire at 30. He's 47 (like me) and still working...
11:22 am
BE11:22am

Which draws some parallels between Kier and problem cases in the construction support sector.

BE11:23am

Part of a big sector thing. I'll cut to the Kier stuff specifically.

BE11:23am

Which raises questions about earnings dropthrough and grumbles about increasing reliance on JVs.

Londonbus FT just tweeted about Wesfarmers. Oh dear. How to burn value with a takeover.
Tundra4 @Londonbus i'm a big4 accountant. i can see AI taking away my job.....
11:24 am
BE11:24am

With a share price down over 25% in the past 12 months and consensus remaining 100% overweight, we seek to assess whether the decline is justified, or more simply a result of wider sector concerns. In our view, significant acquisitions, H1 WCap outflows, heavy historical use of exceptionals, meaningful on- and off-balance-sheet leverage, increasing utilisation of JVs and a forthcoming divisional restructure inevitably raise some concerns, particularly in light of recent issues in the sector.While we appreciate a number of Kier’s attractions – with a strong position within the Highways market, which should see increased spend in the forecast period on assumption of control of the Smart Motorways JV and the expected returns that should be generated from the investments made into residential and commercial property development over the past three years – we believe the shares are not as ‘cheap’ or cash-generative as at first glance, with significant adjustments required to appreciate the full leverage position. We see few potential catalysts to drive a substantial re-rating given the greater level of risk now in the model and, as a result, initiate at Underweight with a 995p price target based on our SOTP valuation, which we view as the most logical way to approach the hybrid business model.

BE11:24am

67 pages, this one. It's a solid bit of work.

BE11:25am

Within this note we highlight a number of areas that raise some uncertainty on the sustainability and cash generation of underlying earnings within the group’s Contracting businesses – namely adjusted cash conversion, which we see as lower than reported in presentations, significant provisions created on acquisition, relatively soft organic earnings progression once adjusting for M&A and a mixed outlook for the sustainability of high payables balances in construction.

11:25 am
BE11:25am

With a growing share of earnings from leveraged joint ventures in Property and Resi, visibility is increasingly challenging and earnings sensitivity increasing.

urgeview @Londonbus - sounds like he's got a shot at freedom to trade when and where he likes anywhere in the world
Londonbus @Tundra4 - Having been on the receiving end of Big 4 people in consultancy advising on re-orgs in my old firm I can see powerpoint taking away their job. Rinse, repeat...
BE11:26am

Matthew Walker's the analyst there, ex I think of Canaccord.

nichoman I work in wealth management - I can see AI taking away my job. have decided I'm going to remake myself as a tech expert and help even slower firms implement the tech that should already have made me redundant
Pseudonym I work in IT and I can see that AI is over-hyped.
wayneJ I am very sceptical about a lot of AI.
Pharma @nichoman, it is tech "experts" that have ensured that hasn't happened yet.
rw42 I work as a performance engineer - i'm happy that whatever is brought in to replace the overhyped AI will still be too slow and need tuning.. :)
Manxish I am about to start working in law - can't see AI taking away my (prospective) job
BE11:28am

And speaking of Canaccord, here's them on the Cross Keys JV. Which, I emphasise, has nothing to do with why they're down today.

Pseudonym There are an awful lot of jobs that are really quite mechanical though, and people are now having to compete with automation. Hence falling wages at the bottom end.
Soundbuy This Al guy's gonna be very busy...........
11:28 am
BE11:28am

The deal looks sensible and includes an attractive partner in the form of Homes England. It is the group's second such JV within its residential business. Over time we understand that up to 40% of the residential division's profits will come from JVs.

Tundra4 As I'm pretty junior there's definitely a sense at the lower grades that AI is biting at our heels. We're constantly told that AI will free us up to be more cerebral, handing off the grunt work to computers. But you need to do the grunt work to understand what you're doing
kim I'm an investor (15 years and counting) in AI (medical) and it is way way overhyped. But fun!
BE11:28am

The JV announced today will clearly be very scalable and allows the group to enjoy its share of anticipated attractive profit growth with limited equity investment. The vehicle will mean the group's residential business is less constrained beyond 2020 and therefore be in a position to deliver more growth. We understand that the debt within the JV will be non- recourse.

undefined
Flaneur @pseudonym - indeed it is. But there will be job losses..
Shinshin Manxish - hmm. Case review ? Contract review ? Contract construction ? Covenant analysis ? All being AI'd already.
Londonbus Mind you, some jobs have vanished with technologu (typing pools - remember them?) - others have not...
Stateless @Flaneur there are always job losses
Pharma I'm with Londonbus. Jobs change, rather than disappear.
Flaneur This is true.
Soundbuy You guys all on your elevenses?
Tundra4 Eleven-2-Twelveses
rw42 The old quote was 'Artificial intelligence is no match for natural stupidity'.. and with AI it's not really intelligence, it's just building enough complex and fuzzy rules to make sure no one really knows why it makes the decisions it makes any more IMO.
FATDAZ @Manxish hate to be a killjoy but disruption of the law ( contracts in particular ) is one of the key aims of Ethereum and its blockchain vai the use of smart contracts though as yet this hasn't materialized of course
Stateless Musk is probably planning on sending a billion people to Mars, so dont worry you'll have something to do.
Flaneur @Soundbuy - Im actually an AI, I dont get 11's....
Manxish @Shin - absolutely, but at the top end there is too much trust involved for clients to feel comfortable dealing heavily with AI. It is more of a threat to non-fee earners and paralegals than to most solicitors (IMO)
Tundra4 Ah Blockchain tech that fabled saviour of providing assurance in audit....
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Sometimes, I wish AI would reach the point that we could release a batch of ROTR-bots to replace you lot that would keep vaguely on subject.

Stateless @RW42 Neural net type AI's do a decent job of approximating the brains process, but the require an unbelievable amount of processing power
BornCynic How about Deutsche Bank - last time it was at this levels PM was calling it a deep value play. Then somebody thanked BE for making a 60% return (hope she sold) and here we are now..................Any thoughts BE / PM ?
Plato the Cook @BE - and how do you know we're not already bots?
Pharma @Stateless can we make a case for a Golgafrinchan Ark Fleet Ship B? I'd put in anyone who works in IoT (internet of things).
Stateless @BE Could there also be a bot on the left to keep the bots on the right entertained
BE11:32am

But I guess we should welcome the engagement. The internet is, after all, very short of places where people can sound off about technologies.

Grouchmonkey Thanks for the Kier stuff. I was interested, anyway!
Tundra4 @Plato the Cook - how very meta of you, channelling your namesake I see
Pharma @BE, if we were bots we would probably pay more attention to what you were writing.
BE11:34am

@BornCynic, on DB. My only argument there was the rights issue-at-a-premium theory. Which I continue to argue would have worked better than what they did, which was not enough.

FATDAZ @RW42 dont want to get to abstract here but saw a Scientific American piece that maintains that its our consciousness that allows us to see and interact with reality and the world around us so perhaps thats the root for AI researchers to pursue ie algos that learn about and experience the world around them independently .....
Tundra4 @Pharma @BE - Would we pass the Turing Test?
Manxish @FATDAZ - perhaps, though I hate to admit I'm pretty cynical when it comes to what the blockchain can and will disrupt!
11:35 am
BE11:35am

Shares at e9.66 live, not much changed on the day.

rw42 @Fatdaz agreed - but it's expensive to train/write specialised neural nets at the moment which are easily fooled - http://www.evolvingai.org/fooling for example. I'm not sure anyone has attempted any human-emulating general purpose AI yet - the compute needs would be obscene.
BornCynic Thanks BE - where do you think things will go from here?
BE11:35am

And no particular news prompt I can see. So .....

undefined

Chris Williams is the Telegraph's media person.

Mouselet Today I noticed that my attempts to stick to capitalism in Latin America have not met with longer-term success. Poor Argentina.
DRichi DB in the news for still attracting lots of applicants on the grad scheme. Not sure if that syas more about long term prospects at DB, or a dearth of possibilities elsewhere
Grouchmonkey So maybe BT didn't overpay so much after all....
Pharma @Tundra4 I increasingly meet people day-to-day who wouldn't pass a Turing test.
Forester Am I the only one here hoping that AI does take my job? Surely much more interesting/worthwhile things in life...otherwise gravestone is going to read "here lies Forester....provided some big companies with debt marginally cheaper than they could get elsewhere"
11:37 am
BE11:37am

Irrelevant to Sky, of course, because Sky's just the world's most complicated domino effect takeover story now.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,359, down 0.5 (-0.04%), High: 1,362, Low: 1,357, Volume: 608.48k
Mouselet And as a result got the money which you used to start the platypus-breeding venture which has made Duckpuss a household name and millions of kids (except the ones stabbed by the poisonous spurs on v0.9beta) happy?
Pseudonym @Forester As AI catches up to your job your value becomes slightly less than the cost of the AI system. You will hit min wage before you get freedom.
BE11:38am

Probably more significant to retailers and the like, given it's yet another way to flog Prime membership and keep consumers inside the tent.

BornCynic @FATDAZ - which would mean............
11:38 am
undefined
BE11:39am

What else is there? How about Capita?

Capita PLC (CPI:LSE): Last: 147.56, up 8.01 (+5.74%), High: 148.52, Low: 144.10, Volume: 3.37m
Shinshin Must be a sigh of relief in the premier league boardroom. Go long Ferrari, Porsche.
Forester @pseudonym is that what really happened to the Luddites? Or ultimately was labour employed elsewhere on at least similar terms?
FATDAZ @Forester agreed as long as one has sufficient finances to see you through from that point on TBH I see a polarised society on marxist lines those that own the means of production Capital Robots . AI commercial three d printers etc and those that don't
Stateless How about we regulate to only allow 1 sport per separately purchasable channel, that way, if i want to watch the cricket, I dont have to fund footballers lifestyles.
Tundra4 @BE on the subject of staying on topic. Would it be maybe worth writing an Alphaville blog setting out some loose guidelines for what the purpose of Markets Live is? Us right-hand side dwellers are certainly an interesting bunch, maybe we need some guidance to help channel our collective brilliance??
Google I understand Bezos was struggling to spend his trillion. Sending some into deep space, the remainder could be quickly consumed buying up Premier League rights...
Flaneur @Shinshin - Not a bad idea. Ferrari working on a SUV so sales volumes will spike sharply in coming years....
11:40 am
BE11:40am

This is Citi pushing.

BE11:41am

Buy, 160p TP — With earnings rebasement, a rebuilt balance sheet and another £105m costs savings targeted post 2018, Capita should have reached its nadir. While industry momentum remains soft, Capita has a reasonably solid revenue base into which new management can reconfigure the business. The early stages of the turnaround narrative should encourage investors and draw attention to the 32% 2020E EV/EBITA discount to the Business Services sector (8.8x v 12.9x).

Flaneur We'll need a slogan too. How about : FTAlphaville 'Beats working'
Soundbuy @ Forester - 'Here lies Forester...........who ironically couldn't see the wood for the trees'
#REF! its good for me to have games on amazon prime, but similiarly to BT its not easy to just buy rights to watch football (can do on now tv for sky). Really should be like NFL in states where you can pay the league directly and not get anything else (I'm never going to watch golf, why pay for it)
Londonbus Any plans to do a live markets live thing again? You know a live event. Make it a Friday again and I can from Riyadh to it...
Woz10 Auto Trader?
BE11:42am

(@Tundra4: we've been going for 12 years or so. It seems a little late to be setting out parameters.)

BornCynic The other thing about Sky was that the receiver that points at the satellite dish is now being configured only to receive Sky. You cannot plug in a Freesat box into the satellite dish you have stuck on your property - it will not work with this new system.Wonder why they have done that.........
Forester Tech taking/replacing jobs is nothing new...are all those ex-typists and secretaries working for minimian wage or have most of them morphed into other useful and rewarding careers?
Stateless #ref - Exactly what im saying
Mouselet Luddites: have you read _Silas Marner_? As far as I can see, automatic looms entirely destroyed a slightly oddly-shaped way of life
Flaneur Markets Live; Skiving behind the bikeshed for grown ups.
11:42 am
BE11:42am

2018 guidance cushion — Our £280m FY18 PBT sits towards the middle of
management guidance and includes £344m EBITA. Inputting all of the known EBITA swings from the FY17 base EBITA, we calculate a £70-80m gap. While some of this could be attributed to underlying margin pressures, partial loss of an estimated £20m in Constructionline & ParkingEye profits and possibly tough comps from other unknown one-off 2017 benefits, we think some of this could reflect management conservatism.

#REF! Discount to the business services sector? Well yeah discount to the high skilled/margin/tech business services names. That's too broad a peer group imo
BE11:42am

Benchmarked double-digit margins — Our detailed benchmarking against peers of Capita’s various revenue end-market exposures suggests that management’s double-digit 2020 EBITA margin target (which assumes c70% retention of the incremental £105m cost savings) should be achievable. Also, our analysis suggests that Capita’s five focus divisions should contribute 80-90% of group EBITA. Software could generate over a quarter of group profits with Contact Centres and HR combined contributing over a third. The UK Central and Local Government segments could represent only 10-15% of profits.

Shinshin @FAT and the mob just storms the castle at that point
FATDAZ @RW42 re AI thanks for the link here is the scientific american piece I referenced https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/coming-to-grips-with-the-implications-of-quantum-mechanics/
Plato the Cook Capita hugely dependent on public sector contracts. What price the risk of a radical Labour government?
BE11:43am

You also have a "straightforward disposal process" for ParkingEye and Constructionline to get net debt back to 1.3x EBITDA by end of 2018, or 2.1x including the pension deficit.

BornCynic @Flaneur - and there was me trying to make a return.......I'm on the wrong site.
11:43 am
BE11:43am

And only a few large contract rebids through to 2020.

Mouselet A radical Labour government which doesn't do large public sector contracts?
Flaneur @Plato - was about to write that. I think punitive performance clauses more likely than renationalisation.
#REF! stateless - would maybe make minority sports suffer (rugby league) currently get paid to buffer out content (I like league). Should we care about that?
Lemmy Plato the Cook: ditto the sector
BE11:44am

undefined
FATDAZ @Shinsin potentially - hence idea of UBI to placate the mob and allow people to do what they want rather than have to
Forester Much as I dislike Capita, I reckon wasare past peak Labour under Corbyn (unless the Tories blow up as a result of Brexit)
11:44 am
BE11:44am

As for Auto Trader -- it's complicated.

Auto Trader Group PLC (AUTO:LSE): Last: 382.60, up 28.6 (+8.08%), High: 386.40, Low: 361.20, Volume: 2.36m
#REF! Mouselet - I think its more that they'll do contracts but will want to be seen to really push the margin down. Don't let those horrible capaitlists make too much (any) money
BE11:45am

Headline figures are fine, as you'd expect with a trading update not long ago.

Plato the Cook @Mouselet A radical Labour government which doesn't abide failure/incompetence
DRichi It's good that you get a sports package with sports you would otherwise watch. helps subsidise lesser known sports and (potentially) can help you discover new fun stuff
11:45 am
BE11:45am

Guidance looks like a warning.

#REF! 1.3x eBITDA ignoring alllllll the operating leases (which are about to come on balance sheet)
Pharma @Mouselet, if they are truly radical it would be back to direct-labour organisations of the 1970s. Excellent way to spend lots of money, though perhaps not if you want results at the end.
Londonbus Surely Capita is just a collection of contracts? Am I missing something?
BE11:46am

But isn't. Because the sellside consensus was already expecting the used car market to contract in YE19 and the granular stuff about financing and that kind of thing suggests that consensus will be hit.

Flaneur Surprised a brand like autotrader hasnt branched off into the parts business. They've got the platform just substitute old ad revenue Deliveroo/Hungry House model for car repairs...
Londonbus @Pharma - I would expect certainly professional services going in house. Not sure about blue collar stuff.
FATDAZ @Mouselett re looms and jacquards use of the chain of punch cards laid the groundwork for the machines and software we are discussing now a pleasing if slightly disturbing symmetry in that I feel
BE11:47am

Merrill's keen.

Pharma @#REF! given the negative margins outsourcers already appear to be on, where would savings be made?
11:47 am
BE11:47am

FY18 results were in line with consensus, with EBIT up 10% yoy, while FY19 guidance is better than we anticipated due to strong uptake of the dealer finance package. As a net result, our estimates are tweaked up across the board (sales up 2%, EBIT 2-3%) post FY18. We are now c. 1% below the company-compiled consensus for FY19, although we believe the buyside expectation was closer to our previous estimates. With good progress on the structural growth drivers and some signs of improvement in the end market ‒ new car sales were +3% in May ‒ we see these results as net positive and reiterate our Buy rating and 490p PO. The shares trade on 17x CY19e P/E, a 6-7x discount to peers such as Rightmove and Scout24.

BE11:47am

The guidance calls for ARPR (average revenue per retailer) to grow less than it did in FY18 (+10%), although the target was not quantified as in prior years. However, the decline in the stock component of ARPR was cited as ‘small’, as much of the weakness, as we noted previously, is coming from consumer, and so not impacting ARPR.

Pharma @Londonbus blue collar is more heavily unionised. It would be taken in-house first.
#REF! Pharma - classic public sector savings, massively underscope the prevision to get cheaper bids then complain 3 years later that its insufficient
Mouselet Ah, Jacquard was only about twenty years after Cartwright
BE11:48am

I think ARPR is actually Average Revenue Per Retailer Forecourt, so should be ARPRF. But I digress.

FATDAZ RE AI / Automation is all about cost of deployment versus humans Canaries in the coal mine are Amazon warehouse workers when their jobs are replaced its time to worry
Mouselet (and developed a loom for making luxury fabrics automatically during the middle of the Napoleonic Wars, which I suppose is a sign that market timing isn't always a thing)
Londonbus @Pharma - blue collar is where you get sharpest gains from outsourcing. Mind if you look a the Guardian I think you'll find insourcing will be Radical Labour's policy. Ticks all the boxes. Never mind cost/deliver.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

There are three drivers of the guided to stronger product growth for FY19: (1) Dealer Finance, which has seen 69% adoption by the installed base (we est. a 3-4% impact); (2) further upsell onto higher-tiered packages; and (3) further adoption of Managing products (e.g., iControl). Moreover, the annual price raise in April has gone ‘well’, meaning that AUTO expects stronger growth from price + product vs. FY18’s +8.3% combined. With our assumption that stock will be -3% for the year (vs. -4% previously), our ARPR growth is +7% for FY19E. Assuming the market stays in recovery mode, we believe the company should be on track to return at/close to double-digit ARPR growth by FY20.

Pharma @Londonbus, exactly. I don't think efficiency would have anything to do with it.
undefined
Londonbus @Pharma - Quite - it's about idelogy. Mind you some outsourcings have been ideologically driven.
BE11:50am

Having started late we're going to have to knock off early. Sorry about that.

Grouchmonkey Amazon deal formally announced now
11:50 am
BE11:51am

I've got to run. Day job intervenes.

FATDAZ @Mouslett the punchards had been developed by two other French guys in 1780s I believe but I thought Jacquard was the first to join them and systemoise their use in factory setting
Grouchmonkey Tnx - bye
BornCynic Thanks BE / ROTR
BE11:51am

There's extra stuff here, if you want it: https://www.ft.com...-8cf3-0c230fa67aec

FATDAZ by all have a good one short and sweet
BornCynic Good luck with the day job..........
Soundbuy Cheers..........
BE11:52am

We'll be back tomorrow, hopefully for more than 40 minutes.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Until then, afternoon all.

Tundra4 Excellent repartee as always. Happy Thursday everyone
DRichi TTFN
Blank canvas thanks everyone
Soundbuy Back to work you lot - AI's on your back.......
Excel Developer bye
